title: 110_hr853
content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress finds that improving population health and reducing medical costs requires preventive methods, there is a need for more public health professionals, only 6,000 physicians are board certified in preventive medicine, preventive medicine can help reduce costs spent on chronic conditions, the number of preventive medicine programs and professionals has decreased, preventive medicine physicians play a unique role in patient care, and a strong public health system relies on a strong preventive medicine workforce. Loan payment assistance is provided for preventive medicine physicians. Loan payment assistance is available for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008 and 2012. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may pay up to $20,000 of their medical education loans. Physicians must submit an application containing required information to receive this assistance. The term "medical education loan" refers to the outstanding principal and interest on a loan for attending a school of medicine. The term "school of medicine" is defined in the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for this program, with appropriations authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. This section introduces a new employer credit for wellness programs under the Internal Revenue Code. The wellness program employer credit under section 38 allows eligible employers to receive a credit equal to 25% of expenses for developing and implementing a qualified wellness program, with a maximum credit of $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must maintain accurate records of preventive services and programs. The term 'eligible employer' refers to an employer who develops and implements a qualified wellness program and keeps accurate records of employee participation. A qualified wellness program is one developed by the employer in consultation with a wellness program expert, conducting health risk assessments. The eligible employer must ensure compliance with privacy measures, conduct health risk assessments, offer preventive services, and provide counseling sessions on various health topics. The eligible employer must provide health programs covering obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression, mental health, heart disease, and maternal and infant health for at least 50% of full-time employees. Qualified employees are full-time employees who participate in these programs. Qualified employees are full-time employees who participate in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered through the employer's wellness program and have undergone a health risk assessment. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program for the taxable year. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to the tax code to include the wellness program employer credit. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A new section, "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT," is added to the Internal Revenue Code for nonrefundable personal credits. The new section "SEC. 25E. WELLNESS PROGRAM PARTICIPANT CREDIT" allows a $200 tax credit for qualified employees who are full-time employees and participate in a qualified wellness program. Qualified participants must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by the wellness program. The term 'qualified participant' refers to an individual who participates in at least 2 annual preventive services or programs offered by a qualified wellness program and undergoes a health risk assessment during the taxable year. A 'qualified wellness program' is a program developed and implemented by an eligible employer in consultation with a wellness program expert. The eligible employer must develop and implement a wellness program in consultation with a wellness program expert. The program should conduct health risk assessments, offer at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force annually, and provide counseling sessions and seminars on smoking, obesity, and stress management. An eligible employer must offer annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, with at least 50% of full-time employees participating. An eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program, keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and other programs, and have at least 50% of full-time employees participate. This section does not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2012. The amendment for the wellness program participant credit under Sec. 25E applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
